poem:
The Ripple of White Coats

In the ward's quiet hum,  
young doctors count coins,  
while the nation listens,  
their fingers mending lives yet unvalued.  
An old physician sighs,  
sees wisdom tangled in strikes—  
a stethoscope's silent plea,  
echoing corridors,  
questions unanswered,  
life's pulse caught in a pay packet,  
time's fragile bindings unspooled.
